contentMetadata.content:
{{coord|50.785848|6.110717|display=title|type:landmark}} {{Infobox company | name = Waggonfabrik Talbot | logo = | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = Bombardier Transportation GmbH (1995-2013, ''part of'')
Talbot Services GmbH. (2013-) | foundation = 1838 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = Aachen | location_country = Germany | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Railway rolling stock manufacturing | products = Wagons, coaches
''later'' Multiple units, trams, double deck rail vehicles | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 500 (January 2011) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage =[http://talbot-services.com talbot-services.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Waggonfabrik Talbot''' was a rolling stock manufacturer founded in [[Aachen]], Germany, in 1838. The company was an early pioneer of self discharging freight wagons, and in the latter part of the twentieth century a major supplier to the Dutch State Railways (Nederlandse Spoorwegen). In the 1990s the company developed the [[Talent (train)|Talent]] passenger train, and was acquired by [[Bombardier Inc.]] As of 2011, the company is part of Bombardier GmbH., and manufactures passenger rolling stock. Since takeover it is also referred to as '''Bombardier Talbot'''. Bombardier announced the closure of the factory in 2012. The factory has been acquired by management and local investors and operates as the independent company '''''Talbot Services''''', providing rail vehicle maintenance and overhaul services since 2013. It has also branched out into other activities, such as the assembly of the [[StreetScooter]]. ==History== [[File:Aachen Talbot-Hauptbau.jpg|Talbot building on ''Jülicher Straße''|thumb]] In 1838, Pierre Pauwels and Hugo Talbot founded the ''Eisenbahn-Waggon-Fabrik Pauwels & Talbot Aachen'' (Pauwels & Talbot railway wagon factory) near the Adalbert gate (''Adalbertsot'') on Adalbertsteinweg.{{cite web|url =http://www.rheinische-industriekultur.de/objekte/aachen/Talbot/talbot.html| title = Rheinische Industriekiltur : Aachen Talbot| work = www.rheinische-indsutriekultur.de|language=de| publisher = Rheinische Industriekultur e.V. }}{{cite book| title = Die rheinischen Sparkassen: Entwicklung und Bedeutung für Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft von den Anfängen bis 1990| author = Hans Pohl| publisher = Franz Steiner Verlag| year = 2001|page =25 |isbn = 3-515-07846-0|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YLHqyBg_XB8C| language =de}} The company was founded to supply wagons to the ''Rheinische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft'' ([[Rhenish Railway Company]]), and was one of the earliest wagon factories in Germany.{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sYdAAAAAcAAJ| title = Handbuch für specielle {spezielle} Eisenbahn-Technik: Bd. 2, Der Eisenbahn-Wagenbau in seinem ganzen Umfange| volume= 2 |author = Edmund Heusinger von Waldegg| publisher = Engelmann| year =1870 |language = de|page = 543}} Belgian and English industrial knowledge played a role in the early wagonworks, in particular English wagon technology, and Belgian engineers acting as [[technology transfer]]ists;{{citation|url = http://www.histech.org/00009_00121_die_aachener_fruehindustrialisier.htm| title = Die Aachener Frühindustrialisierung|author=Silke Fengler|author2 = Stefan Krebs|at =§ 3, 4 | language = de| work = www.histech.org}} Pauwels, a Belgian stagecoach and wagon maker, had the experience to oversee a wagon-making business, having already delivered wagons from his Brussels wagonworks to the ''Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie'' ([[Leipzig-Dresden Railway Company]]), whilst Talbot had the necessary Prussian citizenship to be eligible for the Rhenish Railway contract. New production facilities were opened in the ''Nordbahnhof'' area in 1845. After the initial contract, the company sought orders but was hampered by a dependence on external suppliers, and by disruption due to the [[revolutions of 1848 in the German states]], as well as the distance to the markets; because of transportation difficulties, a factory was built in [[Heidelberg]] in 1842.{{cite book|title=Die belgische Beeinflussung der Frühindustrialisierung im Aachener Raum, ca. 1820-1860 (thesis: Universität Trier )| work =ubttest.opus.hbz-nrw.de |url= http://ubttest.opus.hbz-nrw.de/volltexte/2004/240/pdf/HartmutSchainbergDiss.pdf| author= Hartmut Schainberg |date =April 1997| publisher = Universitätbibliothek Trier|pages=207, 298–302, 307}} Several early German railways were supplied with wagons from Aachen, including the ''Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie'' ([[Leipzig–Dresden Railway Company]]), the ''München-Augsburger Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft'' ([[Munich-Augsburg Railway Company]]), ''Köln-Mindener Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft'' ([[Cologne-Minden Railway Company]]), ''Düsseldorf-Elberfelder Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft'' ([[Düsseldorf-Elberfeld Railway Company]]), ''Main-Neckar-Bahn'' ([[Main-Neckar Railway]]), ''Bergisch-Märkische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft'' ([[Bergisch-Märkische Railway Company]]) and ''Großherzoglich Badische Staatseisenbahnen'' ([[Grand Duchy of Baden State Railway]]);{{cite web|url=http://www.wisoveg.de/rheinland/histo/aachen/his-ac.htm| title = Aachener Eisenbahngeschichte| at = Mit der Eisenbahn kommt die Industrie| work = www.wisoveg.de| access-date = 30 June 2011| language=de}} most of the early lines in Southern Germany got wagons from the plant. After Hugo Talbot's death in 1850, his sons with Peter Herbrand ran the company; after 1855 it was named as ''Talbot & Herbrand''. A new factory was built on ''Jülicher Straße'' in 1860. In 1891, George Talbot developed a new type of wagon - the 'self discharging wagon', which became a major source of sales. A modern plant along North American lines was added in ''''Jülicher Straße'' in the 1890s, with modern equipment including [[air hammer (fabrication)|air hammer]]s, rivetting machines, and electric power for machines. By 1900, the plant employed up to 400 workers. The factory site expanded in the early 1900s; by 1929, the factory employed 1700, and had a full order book, including a large order for express coaches for the Paris–Versailles line. After the interruption of the 1930s [[Great Depression]], a new factory hall was completed, the ''Tannhäuserhalle''. During the [[Second World War]], the factory was heavily damaged, being hit by over 3000 incendiary bombs. The company recovered during the 1950s, and by 1957, accounted for half of German exports of rolling stock. After 1968, the company became the major supplier of rolling stock to the Dutch Railways, [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] (NS).{{#tag:ref|The Dutch company [[Werkspoor]], once a major supplier for the Dutch railways, stopped railway vehicle production in 1972.{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0LNYFznKmZcC|title=Railways in the Netherlands: a brief history, 1834-1994| author = A. J. Veenendaal| publisher = Stanford University Press| year =2001|page =209|isbn=9780804739474}}|group="note"}}{{cite web|url = http://de.bombardier.com/en/site_details_Aachen.htm| title = Bombardier Germany : Aachen|access-date = 30 June 2011| work = de.bombardier.com| publisher = [[Bombardier Transportation]]}} [[File:VT644 RB23.jpg|thumb|The ''Talent'', a multiple unit passenger train in use in various European countries, was developed by Waggonfabrik Talbot.]] In 1994, the [[Talent (train)|Talent]] multiple unit was developed, and in 1995, the factory was acquired by Bombardier. The Talent subsequently entered service on the rail system of Germany,{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/diesel-multiple-units/talent---germany--db-ag-?docID=0901260d80010343|title=Diesel Multiple Unit TALENT Class 643.2 - Germany|access-date=3 July 2011}} Austria{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/single-deck-electric-multiple-units/talent---austria--etw-?docID=0901260d80010486|title=Electrical Multiple Unit TALENT for Regional Service - Austria|access-date=3 July 2011}} and Norway.{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/diesel-multiple-units/talent---norway?docID=0901260d80010353|title=Diesel Multiple Unit TALENT Class 93 - Norway|access-date=3 July 2011}} In late 2012, Bombardier announced the closure of the plant.{{citation| url = http://www.bombardier.com/en/corporate/media-centre/press-releases/details?docID=0901260d802610e8 | title = Bombardier Announces Financial Results for the Third Quarter Ended September 30, 2012 (Press release)| date = 7 November 2012| publisher = Bombardier}}{{citation| url = https://www.welt.de/newsticker/news3/article109985075/Bombardier-schliesst-Bahn-Fahrzeugwerk-in-Aachen.html | title = Bombardier schließt Bahn-Fahrzeugwerk in Aachen| language = de|work = www.welt.de| date = 18 October 2012 }} The plant's remaining contracts were expected to be completed by mid-2013 - lack of orders from the Netherlands contributing to the closure.{{citation| url = http://www1.wdr.de/themen/wirtschaft/bombardierwerk106.html| title = Bombardier-Werk in Aachen schließt: Druck auf Bombardier wächst| language = de|date = 19 October 2012| work =www1.wdr.de}} In July 2013, the plant began operating as ''Talbot Services GmbH.''. An initial order for the factory was the manufacture of [[StreetScooter]] electric road vehicles.{{citation| url = http://www.aachener-nachrichten.de/news/wirtschaft/175-jahre-talbot-mit-der-grossen-bahntradition-in-die-neue-zukunft-1.599835| title = 175 Jahre Talbot: Mit der großen Bahntradition in die neue Zukunft|language = de|first = Berthold| last = Strauch| date = 20 June 2013| work = www.aachener-nachrichten.de }}{{citation| url =http://talbot-services.com/?page_id=2421| title = Profil der TALBOT Services GmbH| work = talbot-services.com| language = de|access-date = 1 Jan 2015}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="note"}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Waggonfabrik Talbot}} *{{cite web|url=http://nmld.locaalspoor.nl/index.php?st1=&st2=&st3=&st4=&st14=&st5=&st6a=equal&st6b=&st7=Talbot&st8=&st13=&st9a=equal&st9b=&st10=&st12=&page=results| title = Resultaten van uw zoekopdracht : Fabrikant: "Talbot"|language = nl|work = nmld.locaalspoor.nl| publisher=Nederlandse Museummaterieel Database|trans-title=Search result for "Talbot" as manufacturer on the Netherlands Museum (rail) Database}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Waggonfabrik Talbot| ]] [[Category:Companies established in 1838]] [[Category:Bombardier Inc. acquisitions]] [[Category:1838 establishments in Prussia]]
contentMetadata.text: 50°47′09″N 6°06′39″E﻿ / ﻿50.785848°N 6.110717°E﻿ / 50.785848; 6.110717 Waggonfabrik Talbot was a rolling stock manufacturer founded in Aachen, Germany, in 1838. The company was an early pioneer of self discharging freight wagons, and in the latter part of the twentieth century a major supplier to the Dutch State Railways (Nederlandse Spoorwegen). In the 1990s the company developed the Talent passenger train, and was acquired by Bombardier Inc. As of 2011, the company is part of Bombardier GmbH., and manufactures passenger rolling stock. Since takeover it is also referred to as Bombardier Talbot. Bombardier announced the closure of the factory in 2012. The factory has been acquired by management and local investors and operates as the independent company Talbot Services, providing rail vehicle maintenance and overhaul services since 2013. It has also branched out into other activities, such as the assembly of the StreetScooter. In 1838, Pierre Pauwels and Hugo Talbot founded the Eisenbahn-Waggon-Fabrik Pauwels & Talbot Aachen (Pauwels & Talbot railway wagon factory) near the Adalbert gate (Adalbertsot) on Adalbertsteinweg. The company was founded to supply wagons to the Rheinische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft (Rhenish Railway Company), and was one of the earliest wagon factories in Germany. Belgian and English industrial knowledge played a role in the early wagonworks, in particular English wagon technology, and Belgian engineers acting as technology transferists; Pauwels, a Belgian stagecoach and wagon maker, had the experience to oversee a wagon-making business, having already delivered wagons from his Brussels wagonworks to the Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie (Leipzig-Dresden Railway Company), whilst Talbot had the necessary Prussian citizenship to be eligible for the Rhenish Railway contract. New production facilities were opened in the Nordbahnhof area in 1845. After the initial contract, the company sought orders but was hampered by a dependence on external suppliers, and by disruption due to the revolutions of 1848 in the German states, as well as the distance to the markets; because of transportation difficulties, a factory was built in Heidelberg in 1842. Several early German railways were supplied with wagons from Aachen, including the Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie (Leipzig–Dresden Railway Company), the München-Augsburger Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft (Munich-Augsburg Railway Company), Köln-Mindener Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft (Cologne-Minden Railway Company), Düsseldorf-Elberfelder Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft (Düsseldorf-Elberfeld Railway Company), Main-Neckar-Bahn (Main-Neckar Railway), Bergisch-Märkische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft (Bergisch-Märkische Railway Company) and Großherzoglich Badische Staatseisenbahnen (Grand Duchy of Baden State Railway); most of the early lines in Southern Germany got wagons from the plant. After Hugo Talbot's death in 1850, his sons with Peter Herbrand ran the company; after 1855 it was named as Talbot & Herbrand. A new factory was built on Jülicher Straße in 1860. In 1891, George Talbot developed a new type of wagon - the 'self discharging wagon', which became a major source of sales. A modern plant along North American lines was added in ''Jülicher Straße in the 1890s, with modern equipment including air hammers, rivetting machines, and electric power for machines. By 1900, the plant employed up to 400 workers. The factory site expanded in the early 1900s; by 1929, the factory employed 1700, and had a full order book, including a large order for express coaches for the Paris–Versailles line. After the interruption of the 1930s Great Depression, a new factory hall was completed, the Tannhäuserhalle. During the Second World War, the factory was heavily damaged, being hit by over 3000 incendiary bombs. The company recovered during the 1950s, and by 1957, accounted for half of German exports of rolling stock. After 1968, the company became the major supplier of rolling stock to the Dutch Railways, Nederlandse Spoorwegen (NS). In 1994, the Talent multiple unit was developed, and in 1995, the factory was acquired by Bombardier. The Talent subsequently entered service on the rail system of Germany, Austria and Norway. In late 2012, Bombardier announced the closure of the plant. The plant's remaining contracts were expected to be completed by mid-2013 - lack of orders from the Netherlands contributing to the closure. In July 2013, the plant began operating as Talbot Services GmbH.. An initial order for the factory was the manufacture of StreetScooter electric road vehicles. The Dutch company Werkspoor, once a major supplier for the Dutch railways, stopped railway vehicle production in 1972. "Bombardier Germany : Aachen". de.bombardier.com. Bombardier Transportation. Retrieved 30 June 2011. "Rheinische Industriekiltur : Aachen Talbot". www.rheinische-indsutriekultur.de (in German). Rheinische Industriekultur e.V. Hans Pohl (2001). Die rheinischen Sparkassen: Entwicklung und Bedeutung für Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft von den Anfängen bis 1990 (in German). Franz Steiner Verlag. p. 25. ISBN 3-515-07846-0. Hartmut Schainberg (April 1997). Die belgische Beeinflussung der Frühindustrialisierung im Aachener Raum, ca. 1820-1860 (thesis: Universität Trier ) (PDF). pp. 207, 298–302, 307. {{cite book}}: |work= ignored (help) Edmund Heusinger von Waldegg (1870). Handbuch für specielle {spezielle} Eisenbahn-Technik: Bd. 2, Der Eisenbahn-Wagenbau in seinem ganzen Umfange (in German). Vol. 2. Engelmann. p. 543. Silke Fengler; Stefan Krebs, "Die Aachener Frühindustrialisierung", www.histech.org (in German), § 3, 4 "Aachener Eisenbahngeschichte". www.wisoveg.de (in German). Mit der Eisenbahn kommt die Industrie. Retrieved 30 June 2011. A. J. Veenendaal (2001). Railways in the Netherlands: a brief history, 1834-1994. Stanford University Press. p. 209. ISBN 9780804739474. {{coord|50.785848|6.110717|display=title|type:landmark}} {{Infobox company | name = Waggonfabrik Talbot | logo = | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = Bombardier Transportation GmbH (1995-2013, part of)

later Multiple units, trams, double deck rail vehicles | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 500 (January 2011) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage =talbot-services.com | footnotes = | intl = }} Waggonfabrik Talbot was a rolling stock manufacturer founded in [[Aachen]], Germany, in 1838. The company was an early pioneer of self discharging freight wagons, and in the latter part of the twentieth century a major supplier to the Dutch State Railways (Nederlandse Spoorwegen). In the 1990s the company developed the [[Talent (train)|Talent]] passenger train, and was acquired by [[Bombardier Inc.]] As of 2011, the company is part of Bombardier GmbH., and manufactures passenger rolling stock. Since takeover it is also referred to as Bombardier Talbot. Bombardier announced the closure of the factory in 2012. The factory has been acquired by management and local investors and operates as the independent company Talbot Services, providing rail vehicle maintenance and overhaul services since 2013. It has also branched out into other activities, such as the assembly of the [[StreetScooter]].

texts.title: History
texts.value:
[[File:Aachen Talbot-Hauptbau.jpg|Talbot building on Jülicher Straße|thumb]]
In 1838, Pierre Pauwels and Hugo Talbot founded the Eisenbahn-Waggon-Fabrik Pauwels & Talbot Aachen (Pauwels & Talbot railway wagon factory) near the Adalbert gate (Adalbertsot) on Adalbertsteinweg.<ref name="ta">{{cite web|url =http://www.rheinische-industriekultur.de/objekte/aachen/Talbot/talbot.html| title = Rheinische Industriekiltur : Aachen Talbot| work = www.rheinische-indsutriekultur.de|language=de| publisher = Rheinische Industriekultur e.V. }}</ref><ref name="spark">{{cite book| title = Die rheinischen Sparkassen: Entwicklung und Bedeutung für Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft von den Anfängen bis 1990| author = Hans Pohl| publisher = Franz Steiner Verlag| year = 2001|page =25 |isbn = 3-515-07846-0|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YLHqyBg_XB8C| language =de}}</ref> The company was founded to supply wagons to the Rheinische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft ([[Rhenish Railway Company]]),<ref name="the"/> and was one of the earliest wagon factories in Germany.<ref>{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sYdAAAAAcAAJ| title = Handbuch für specielle {spezielle} Eisenbahn-Technik: Bd. 2, Der Eisenbahn-Wagenbau in seinem ganzen Umfange| volume= 2 |author = Edmund Heusinger von Waldegg| publisher = Engelmann| year =1870 |language = de|page = 543}}</ref>

Belgian and English industrial knowledge played a role in the early wagonworks, in particular English wagon technology, and Belgian engineers acting as [[technology transfer]]ists;<ref name="his">{{citation|url = http://www.histech.org/00009_00121_die_aachener_fruehindustrialisier.htm| title = Die Aachener Frühindustrialisierung|author=Silke Fengler|author2 = Stefan Krebs|at =§ 3, 4 | language = de| work = www.histech.org}}</ref> Pauwels, a Belgian stagecoach and wagon maker, had the experience to oversee a wagon-making business, having already delivered wagons from his Brussels wagonworks to the Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie ([[Leipzig-Dresden Railway Company]]), whilst Talbot had the necessary Prussian citizenship to be eligible for the Rhenish Railway contract.<ref name="the"/> New production facilities were opened in the Nordbahnhof area in 1845.<ref name="ta"/>

After the initial contract, the company sought orders but was hampered by a dependence on external suppliers, and by disruption due to the [[revolutions of 1848 in the German states]],<ref name="spark"/> as well as the distance to the markets;<ref name="his"/> because of transportation difficulties, a factory was built in [[Heidelberg]] in 1842.<ref name="the">{{cite book|title=Die belgische Beeinflussung der Frühindustrialisierung im Aachener Raum, ca. 1820-1860 (thesis: Universität Trier )| work =ubttest.opus.hbz-nrw.de |url= http://ubttest.opus.hbz-nrw.de/volltexte/2004/240/pdf/HartmutSchainbergDiss.pdf| author= Hartmut Schainberg |date =April 1997| publisher = Universitätbibliothek Trier|pages=207, 298–302, 307}}</ref>

Several early German railways were supplied with wagons from Aachen,<ref name="spark"/> including the Leipzig-Dresdner Eisenbahn-Compagnie ([[Leipzig–Dresden Railway Company]]),<ref name="the"/> the München-Augsburger Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft ([[Munich-Augsburg Railway Company]]), Köln-Mindener Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft ([[Cologne-Minden Railway Company]]), Düsseldorf-Elberfelder Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft ([[Düsseldorf-Elberfeld Railway Company]]), Main-Neckar-Bahn ([[Main-Neckar Railway]]), Bergisch-Märkische Eisenbahn-Gesellschaft ([[Bergisch-Märkische Railway Company]]) and Großherzoglich Badische Staatseisenbahnen ([[Grand Duchy of Baden State Railway]]);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wisoveg.de/rheinland/histo/aachen/his-ac.htm| title = Aachener Eisenbahngeschichte| at = Mit der Eisenbahn kommt die Industrie| work = www.wisoveg.de| access-date = 30 June 2011| language=de}}</ref> most of the early lines in Southern Germany got wagons from the plant.<ref name="the"/>

After Hugo Talbot's death in 1850, his sons with Peter Herbrand ran the company; after 1855 it was named as Talbot & Herbrand.<ref name="the"/> A new factory was built on Jülicher Straße in 1860.<ref name = "ta"/>

In 1891, George Talbot developed a new type of wagon - the 'self discharging wagon', which became a major source of sales. A modern plant along North American lines was added in 'Jülicher Straße in the 1890s, with modern equipment including [[air hammer (fabrication)|air hammer]]s, rivetting machines, and electric power for machines. By 1900, the plant employed up to 400 workers.<ref name = "ta"/>

The factory site expanded in the early 1900s; by 1929, the factory employed 1700, and had a full order book, including a large order for express coaches for the Paris–Versailles line. After the interruption of the 1930s [[Great Depression]], a new factory hall was completed, the Tannhäuserhalle. During the [[Second World War]], the factory was heavily damaged, being hit by over 3000 incendiary bombs. The company recovered during the 1950s, and by 1957, accounted for half of German exports of rolling stock.<ref name="ta"/>

After 1968, the company became the major supplier of rolling stock to the Dutch Railways, [[Nederlandse Spoorwegen]] (NS).<ref name="bm">{{cite web|url = http://de.bombardier.com/en/site_details_Aachen.htm| title = Bombardier Germany : Aachen|access-date = 30 June 2011| work = de.bombardier.com| publisher = [[Bombardier Transportation]]}}</ref>

[[File:VT644 RB23.jpg|thumb|The Talent, a multiple unit passenger train in use in various European countries, was developed by Waggonfabrik Talbot.]]
In 1994, the [[Talent (train)|Talent]] multiple unit was developed, and in 1995, the factory was acquired by Bombardier.<ref name="bm"/> The Talent subsequently entered service on the rail system of Germany,<ref name="TALENT 643.2 - Germany">{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/diesel-multiple-units/talent---germany--db-ag-?docID=0901260d80010343|title=Diesel Multiple Unit TALENT Class 643.2 - Germany|access-date=3 July 2011}}</ref> Austria<ref name="TALENT for Regional Service - Austria">{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/single-deck-electric-multiple-units/talent---austria--etw-?docID=0901260d80010486|title=Electrical Multiple Unit TALENT for Regional Service - Austria|access-date=3 July 2011}}</ref> and Norway.<ref name="TALENT Class 93 - Norway">{{cite web|url=http://www.bombardier.com/en/transportation/products-services/rail-vehicles/commuter-and-regional-trains/diesel-multiple-units/talent---norway?docID=0901260d80010353|title=Diesel Multiple Unit TALENT Class 93 - Norway|access-date=3 July 2011}}</ref>

In late 2012, Bombardier announced the closure of the plant.<ref>{{citation| url = http://www.bombardier.com/en/corporate/media-centre/press-releases/details?docID=0901260d802610e8 | title = Bombardier Announces Financial Results for the Third Quarter Ended September 30, 2012 (Press release)| date = 7 November 2012| publisher = Bombardier}}</ref><ref>{{citation| url  = https://www.welt.de/newsticker/news3/article109985075/Bombardier-schliesst-Bahn-Fahrzeugwerk-in-Aachen.html | title = Bombardier schließt Bahn-Fahrzeugwerk in Aachen| language = de|work = www.welt.de| date = 18 October 2012 }}</ref> The plant's remaining contracts were expected to be completed by mid-2013 - lack of orders from the Netherlands contributing to the closure.<ref>{{citation| url = http://www1.wdr.de/themen/wirtschaft/bombardierwerk106.html| title = Bombardier-Werk in Aachen schließt: Druck auf Bombardier wächst| language = de|date = 19 October 2012| work  =www1.wdr.de}}</ref>

In July 2013, the plant began operating as Talbot Services GmbH.. An initial order for the factory was the manufacture of [[StreetScooter]] electric road vehicles.<ref>{{citation| url = http://www.aachener-nachrichten.de/news/wirtschaft/175-jahre-talbot-mit-der-grossen-bahntradition-in-die-neue-zukunft-1.599835| title = 175 Jahre Talbot: Mit der großen Bahntradition in die neue Zukunft|language = de|first = Berthold| last = Strauch| date = 20 June 2013| work =  www.aachener-nachrichten.de }}</ref><ref>{{citation| url  =http://talbot-services.com/?page_id=2421| title = Profil der TALBOT Services GmbH| work = talbot-services.com| language = de|access-date = 1 Jan 2015}}</ref>
